p.content: Pronouns come in various types, including personal pronouns, possessives, reflexives, reciprocals, and indefinites. These pronouns normally stand alone in the place of a nominal phrase, but they can also be modified by a partitive phrase and in some languages may be modified by determiners and quantifiers. Each of these types and issues will be looked at in turn, after covering the agreement features on all types of pronouns.
Pronouns normally have either more than or the same number of agreement features as nouns have. The following chart shows the agreement features used for pronouns in

All languages have independent personal pronouns which are separate words that may appear in all the positions that nouns or nominal phrases may. Some languages also have dependent forms of the personal pronouns which attach to another word in the sentence.

case.caseText: does not have a separate set of dependent personal pronouns.
has dependent personal pronouns as well as the independent personal pronouns. Both sets of personal pronouns will be presented here, with the independent forms covered first.

p.content: Personal pronouns normally have either more than or the same number of case features as nouns have.
does not have any case distinctions, so there is only a single set of pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence, as exemplified here.
has a nominative-accusative case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns for subjects, objects, and possessors. The independent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position are:
The independent personal pronouns which can appear in object position are:
The independent personal pronouns which can appear in possessor position are:

has an ergative-absolutive case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns that can be used as subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. The independent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of transitive verbs are:
The independent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of intransitive verbs or in object position of transitive verbs are:
The independent personal pronouns which can appear in possessor position are:

has a split case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns that are normally used as subjects, objects, and possessors, plus some special sets which are used in the split ergativity cases. The independent personal pronouns which normally appear in subject position are:
The independent personal pronouns which normally appear in object position are:
The independent personal pronouns which normally appear in possessor position are:
The independent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity are:
The independent personal pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity are:
Turning now to the dependent pronouns, as seen above
does not have any case distinctions, so there is only a single set of pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence, as exemplified here.
Turning now to the dependent pronouns, as seen above
has a nominative-accusative case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns for subjects, objects, and possessors. The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position are:
The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in object position are:
The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in possessor position are:
Turning now to the dependent pronouns, as seen above

has an ergative-absolutive case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns that can be used as subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of transitive verbs are:
The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of intransitive verbs or in object position of transitive verbs are:
The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in possessor position are:
Turning now to the dependent pronouns, as seen above

has a split case system, so there are distinct sets of pronouns that are normally used as subjects, objects, and possessors, plus some special sets which are used in the split ergativity cases. The dependent personal pronouns which normally appear in subject position are:
The dependent personal pronouns which normally appear in object position are:
The dependent personal pronouns which normally appear in possessor position are:
The dependent personal pronouns which can appear in subject position of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity are:
The dependent personal pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity are:
For further details about how the dependent pronouns may be used, see sections
and
where verbal agreement and missing subjects (pro-drop) are discussed.
Many languages also have possessive pronouns which can stand alone, such as
and
in English. These are distinct from those pronouns which can occur in possessor position, such as
and
, which were exemplified under personal pronouns above.

case.caseText: does not have any
has

p.content: possessive pronouns that stand alone as a nominal phrase.

case.caseText: not built by adding an affix to the personal pronouns. They are a distinct set.
built by adding an affix to the personal pronouns.
built by adding an affix to the personal pronouns, though some forms are distinct, stand alone pronouns.

text.content: The possessive pronouns are given here, beginning with first person, then second person, then third person:

p.content: Reflexives are another type of pronouns that most languages have. They occur only in the same case as direct objects and normally must agree with the subject in person, gender, and number features. Examples in English are:
and

. Some languages have a completely separate set of pronoun forms for reflexives, others use a phrase which consists of a noun (usually meaning ‘self’) that is possessed by the pronoun that refers back to the subject, some languages have a verbal affix which indicates reflexive action, and some languages do not distinguish reflexive constructions at all.

case.caseText: does not have any type of reflexives.
has a verbal affix to indicate reflexive action.
has reflexives
are built by adding an affix to another pronoun.
are a distinct set of pronouns.
are phrases consisting of a certain noun with a pronoun as the possessor.

text.content: The forms used for reflexives are given here, beginning with first person, then second person, then third person:

p.content: Some examples with a reflexive used in object position of a simple sentence are:

Reciprocals are similar to reflexives except that they only occur with plural subjects. They may be formed in the same way reflexives are, or they may be distinct. For example, in English, the reciprocal forms are phrases:
and

. Some languages use only a verbal affix to indicate reciprocal action of the plural subject, others have separate pronouns, others use a possessed noun phrase or a quantified noun phrase (as in English), and some do not mark reciprocal action at all.

case.caseText: does not have any type of reciprocals.
uses a verbal affix to indicate reciprocal action.
has reciprocals
are built by adding an affix to another pronoun.
are a distinct set of pronouns.
are phrases consisting of a certain noun with a pronoun as the possessor.
are special quantified noun phrases.

p.content: Some examples of reciprocals in sentences are:
In English, indefinites include
, etc. Also,

are negative versions of the indefinite pronouns. Note that these are made up of a quantifier (positive or negative) plus an indefinite generic noun. Some languages may not merge them into a single word, as in
for English.
In

case.caseText: all of the positive indefinites are nominal phrases, rather than being single-word pronouns.
some or all of the positive indefinites are merged into single-word pronouns. Examples of the positive indefinite pronouns include:

p.content: In

case.caseText: all of the negative indefinites are nominal phrases, rather than being single-word pronouns.
some or all of the negative indefinites are merged into single-word pronouns. Examples of the negative indefinite pronouns include:

p.content: In

case.caseText: there are no negative indefinite pronouns and no negative indefinite nominal phrases either, since the language does not have any means of negating a nominal phrase.

all of the negative indefinites are merged into single-word pronouns. There are no negative indefinite nominal phrases, since the language does not have any means of negating a nominal phrase. Examples of the negative indefinite pronouns include:

p.content: Examples of positive indefinite nominal phrases
include:
Examples of negative indefinite nominal phrases
include:

for examples of the negative elements used in sentences and discussion of the negation constructions in

section2.secTitle: Pronouns as the Head of a Nominal Phrase

p.content: Though pronouns and also demonstratives, quantifiers, and numbers can stand alone as a nominal phrase in the right context, sometimes modifiers are also allowed. In most languages, these elements cannot be modified by possessors, adjectives, or other quantifiers, although they can be modified by a degree word, an article and/or a demonstrative. English examples of this type include the following:
and
Examples of this type in
include:
In addition, it is possible to have a pronoun, demonstrative, or quantifier modified by a relative clause, as in
p.langData: all those who are going with us
p.content: and
p.langData: only these two that I saw
p.content: . Examples of this type in
, included in full sentences are:
Finally, these categories can also be modified by a partitive phrase (or other PP), as in
and
. Examples of this type in
include:

This distribution discussed for English can be accounted for by classifying allow pronouns, demonstratives, quantifiers, and numbers as NPs (rather than DPs) in the expanded DP tree structure for nominal phrases. However, some languages allow pronouns to be modified by possessors and adjectives as well, so the correct category in that case is N. A few languages may require pronouns to stand alone without any modification at all, making them only DPs. (Possessive, reflexive, and reciprocal pronouns are always DPs, since they must stand alone.)
For
, the correct category or level in the tree structure for personal pronouns and other elements which can occur without a head noun is

case.caseText: NP, like in English, because they can be modified by
N, because they can be modified by all the same categories as nouns can, including adjectives and possessors.
DP, because they must stand alone in the place of a whole nominal phrase, with no modifiers allowed.
degree words,
demonstratives,
articles,
demonstratives, articles,

text.content: relative clauses and PPs, but not by possessors or adjectives.

p.content: The optional PP occurs

case.caseText: before
after

p.content: the element acting as the head of the nominal phrase.
